settings.text: Cashmere is one of the rarest and finest materials in the world. It is incredibly warm, super soft, can last for years - as long as it is cared for properly - and it lies at the heart of Chinti & Parker’s collections. But, what exactly is it? And, with the spotlight on fashion more than ever, how can brands ensure the cashmere they use is both ethical and sustainable?
With 150+ species planted across their global sites, Treeapp prides itself on transparency via the online open source platform Restor.eco.

settings.grid-content:
Where does cashmere come from?

Cashmere has been produced and used for hundreds of years. It is thought that cashmere was first used in garments around the 13th century in the Kashmir region of India. From this time until the 19th century, cashmere was reserved for Indian and Iranian rulers during political and religious ceremonies.

By the 18th century, cashmere was being exported to the West where it became very popular in Europe, particularly France and Scotland.

In the present day, the majority of cashmere still comes from Asia.

How is cashmere made?


Unlike other yarns, such as wool, cashmere comes from goats rather than sheep. Here at Chinti & Parker, our cashmere comes from the Capra hircus goat in Mongolia, Northern China. The goats that produce these fibres have a fleece with two layers; the top is wiry and coarse, and the undercoat is super soft. This is the cashmere, and it acts as an insulating layer to help the goats survive extremely cold weather conditions.

Our cashmere supplier is based in Inner Mongolia, where they have a fantastic relationship with the goat herders who breed the animals. They also work on a ‘vertical model’, which means that the entire process, from start to finish, is handled by the same supplier. You can read more about our supply chain here.

As temperatures start to rise after winter, the goats shed their coats naturally. This is when our suppliers will comb out the fine hair gently - without harming the goats - and separate the two coats by hand.

The harvested fibres are sent to a laboratory to be examined where their quality is determined. If the quality is deemed high enough, they will be spun into cashmere in mills.

settings.text: Just as the archipelago is famed for its laid-back attitude, our PF23 collection invites its wearer to embrace slow living. Kick back in cashmere co-ords, show off sun-kissed limbs in thigh-skimming shorts and shrug on cardigans for an instant hit of cool. A dream destination wardrobe – that’s just as good on home turf – awaits.

Is cashmere ethical and sustainable?

Cashmere is a rare material, and it can take between four and eight goats to make a single cashmere sweater. Because of this, cashmere was deemed an expensive luxury, something that was cared for and passed on in the family.

The negative effects of fast fashion on the environment are well-documented, as are the ethical implications. And unfortunately, the impact of fast fashion has started to spread into the cashmere industry, where it’s not uncommon to find cashmere products such as scarves and gloves at lower prices than they should be.

There are a number of factors that contribute to cashmere being deemed ethical. This includes the goats being well cared for, wool harvested at the correct time of year, demand for cashmere kept low enough as to reduce the environmental impact from farming, and workers paid fairly and given good working conditions. If these are all met to a high standard, there is no reason why cashmere cannot be an ethical material

settings.grid-content:
How can I be sure my cashmere is ethical?


As with most products, cheap luxury products are usually too good to be true. If something is sold at less than it is worth, that often means a step has gone awry during production. This could be mistreatment of the animal providing the material, or the workers who create the garments.

Always research the brand you are buying from before purchasing. Look for transparency in their supply chains; does the brand provide clear information about where their fabric is sourced and how it is handled from start to finish? Any cashmere brand worth their money will be eager to present this information prominently.

High-quality cashmere products are an investment and should feel as such. Cashmere should be cared for and stored properly, so that it will last for years to come, and can even be passed on to the next generation.
